body:
@pluskid I tested this new patch.
It seems it still having shape compatible problem.

Could you please have a look at my source code, to see if my bucket setup (a tuple of encoder_len and decoder_len) is OK with your current architecture.

Personally I want to test it on Windows, but not enough time right now.
i see, can you help to update the dmlc-core's S3 support? Thanks!
@antinucleon can you look into this?
You need to put CUDNN into LD_LIBRARY_PATH, as well as link it during compiltation
The memory estimation is only on node cost, the actual cost can be higher than the node cost, because temp space are needed for convolution and cudnn
see last block of https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/notebooks/predict-with-pretrained-model.ipynb

I think a better approach could be add a process iterator that takes the callback, and chains with the ImageRecordIter.

So it won't affect the current ImageRecordIter explicitly

Meanwhile, one more thing that might be worth checking: we require the batch-size to be the same for all buckets.  You can try to insert print statements before [this line](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/executor_manager.py#L81) just to see what `d_src[slice_idx].shape` and `d_dst` and this might give us some hint on what potentially went wrong.

@revilokeb  thanks for your answer, here are answer of your questions 
1. learning from scratch.
2. using train_imagenet.py.
3. the training accuracy i get after training start is 0.02 and rise to 0.75 after 7 epoch.  
    --- if you have  accuracy problem here may be the answer: A commonly mistake is forgetting shuffle the image list during packing. This will lead fail of training, eg. `accuracy` keeps 0.001 for several rounds.

I guess it is caused by different OS/cuda version. Other people have
encountered similar issues. Currently, the binary packages are compiled on
Windows 10, x64, with CUDA 7.5. What are your configurations?

@pluskid I found what is wrong in my code.
As you suggest, the provide data in data iter and batch should be the same.
But in my code, they have the same data, but in different order, result in some input data and parameter mixed up. After reordering the data iter, the error disappear.

Thank you very much for your suggestion and help.

Hi,

Yes, I have just tested. It appears to be working.

Thank you very much!

Regards,
Slawek

@tqchen @piiswrong  I have modified the "batch_norm-inl.h" file, but I am wondering if I have to modify the "cudnn_batch_norm-inl.h". I found that even I compile mxnet with use_cudnn = 1. I am still using the "batch_norm-inl.h" except I explicitly define my symbol as

```
bn = mx.symbol.CuDNNBatchNorm(data=data, name="bn")
```

Is this supposed to work like this? I thought I was like after compiling with "use_cudnn = 1". The program will call Cudnn version automatically even I use "mx.symbol.BatchNorm" to define my symbol. Could you explain to me a little bit how this works and I will send a PR later. Thanks.

And can you tell me how to save the whole trained model,I think this will be very convenient.

@tornadomeet I think we can change deconv back to no_bias =true for default.

BTW, is the gradient correctly computed for bias in deconv?

The whole trained model is just a dictionary of array name to ndarrays. arguments starts with 'arg:' and auxiliary states starts with 'aux:'
We can make a c_api for this. You are welcome to do it if you are interested.

@piiswrong yes, when using bias in deconv, i think the gradient is computed correctly.

Then we will not need to change any code in the fcn-xs example. thank you for your patience!

Any implementation difference comparing against Caffe? 

I am finetuning the Caltech101 dataset with the pre-trained GoogleNet model (converted from Caffe). With exactly the same hyper-parameters (learning rate, wd, momentum, etc.), it seems that MXNet converges much slower that Caffe. Is there any hyper-parameter that I should scale accordingly?

@topepo Hi, I think you can use `sink`.

``` r
tc <- textConnection(NULL, "w") 
sink(tc) 
model <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(softmax, X=train.x, y=train.y,
                                     ctx=devices, num.round=3, array.batch.size=100,
                                     learning.rate=0.07, momentum=0.9,  eval.metric=mx.metric.accuracy,
                                     initializer=mx.init.uniform(0.07),
                                     batch.end.callback=mx.callback.log.train.metric(100))
sink() 
close(tc)
```

Great to see the issue. Looking forward to the c api.
Also I will test distributed training on multi-machines with scala package these days.

For training, which means is_train==True, the mean is calculated by using the batch statistics, and so is the var. After this the data is subtracted by the mean and divided by the var. This happens in forward phase. In backward, apart from back propagate the error, the moving_mean and moving_var get updated  by using momentum. If your momentum is small, the moving_mean and moving_var can change a little bit fast. For inference, the batch_mean and batch_var are no longer calculated. Instead, it uses moving_mean and moving_var as kind of global statistics.

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/223fd62bbcfd2ec03720533c37ddb01893f0be25/example/autoencoder/solver.py#L64

```
        if debug:
            sym = sym.get_internals()
            blob_names = sym.list_outputs()
            sym_group = []
            for i in range(len(blob_names)):
                if blob_names[i] not in args:
                    x = sym[i]
                    if blob_names[i] not in output_names:
                        x = mx.symbol.BlockGrad(x, name=blob_names[i])
                    sym_group.append(x)
            sym = mx.symbol.Group(sym_group)
```

Fine tuning models is such a common use case that it should become a first class API instead of a debug code snippet.
The hacky way to block gradients is https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1538#issuecomment-196691988.
I think you should define your label as 0 and 1, where 0 is membrane and 1 is not. It is not a good option to use 255 unless you want this label to be ignored. @tmquan
@piiswrong

@ascust 
Thank you for response in this thread. 
Actually, I tried that too as following:
I set the output from the network as (30,2,512,512) where (30,:0:,512,512) is the label of non-membrane and (30,:1:,512,512) for membrane classification. 

Then I set the deconvolutional output as a **LogisticRegressionOutput** as following:
`sm   = mx.symbol.LogisticRegressionOutput(data=deconv_out, name="softmax")`

In contrast, the example on fcn-xs folder said that I should use the **SoftmaxOutput** layer to make a prediction on entire segmentation. 

It confused me and I am struggling with that issue quite a bit. 

Best regards,

I have re-designed the finetune api, which is available at https://github.com/taoari/mxnet/blob/finetune-api/example/finetune-api/README.md, I will send another PR once PR1570 and PR1617 are merged.

It is caffe-flavored, and is quite easy to use. For example, fine-tuning Caltech101 with the inception-bn model:

```
train_imagenet.py --solver finetune_caltech101_inception.yml --gpus 0
```
- finetune_caltech101_inception.yml

```
network: inception-bn

data_dir: ../data/caltech101
dataset: caltech101
num_classes: 102
num_examples: 3060
batch_size: 25

lr: 0.0005
lr_factor: 0.1
lr_factor_epoch: 320
momentum: 0.9
wd: 0.0005

num_epochs: 800
kv_store: local

model_prefix: finetune_caltech101_inception
finetune_from: ../share/inception-bn/Inception_BN-0039.params
checkpoint_epoch: 80
eval_epoch: 16
```

Yes, that is one solution. The problem is that, if you want to drop this into existing cross-validation code that might be running in parallel, it gets more complicated (than a `verbose` option). I submitted a PR with an option yesterday.
I wasn't aware of this PR before opening https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/1633 which used the composite design patten to simplify the API.
Directed here by https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1567#issuecomment-196757098.

Another ad-hoc method is two-stage training. To only train newly added layers such as a fully connected layer with a number of classes different from that of the original network, the first stage trains a cloned network with BlockGrad added after the internal layers. The internal layers parameters are still updated for the reason in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1340#issuecomment-174166248. The second stage trains the cloned network with all the BlockGrad symbols removed.

Inspired by the following codes.
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/d717c42025eeb0259e1e3e63d47a84f67a3740d3/tools/accnn/utils.py
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/cb8300739de673ed81540192f5129a58ff5ba456/tools/accnn/acc_conv.py
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1538#issuecomment-196691988

@futurely My experiments show that two-stage training is not a good idea. If you first train a model only allowing changes of the final fully connected layers, it is OK. But in the second stage, the model will explode quickly after several iterations.

But it might be OK in the first stage to allow more layers to change.

My point was that I'm not having any trouble with fine tuning networks. I've been able to accomplish this previously having already referenced the issues you are linking from your previous helpful posts. The manner in which fine tuning is performed was not why this issue was opened. I don't disagree that the fine tuning API could use some refactoring. But, again, this is not the point of this issue. I'm closing now that focus had been derailed.

LogisticRegressionOutput is for binary classification, it is supposed to work. Since I never use this layer before, I can not say much about it. Anyway, SoftmaxOutput is for Multiclass classification and binary classification is only a special case, I am sure this will work. Just like your settings, if 30 is your batch size, there is a (2, 512, 512) score map for each image in the batch. For prediction task, you can simply choose use argmax along the first axis.

Thanks for the answer, it cleared a lot of things for me. I have another question, in the following, the formula for calculating the transform in the validation phase is given:

![batchnorm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17207330/13786541/5aa44e50-ea95-11e5-96bc-8899c64c3d5e.png)

So, the learned gamma and beta is combined with the moving_mean and moving_var in order to get the final transform. Does the BatchNorm operator calculates it in that way as well, like in the line 11: Divide the learned gamma by the square root of the moving variance plus epsilon, scale the input x with that value and add [beta minus (gamma times moving_mean) divided by (square root of the moving variance plus epsilon)]  Do we have the same transformation, when is_train==False in the forward pass?
You have 2 conv layers. The layer one requires more memory

get_internals gives you all internal features.
You can also use mx.sym.Group to group multiple symbols.
The output will have multiple ndarrays

@tornadomeet @tqchen : Kindly provide suggestions on this.

I think so, in the original C++ file, it is like:

```
Assign(out, req[batchnorm::kOut], broadcast<1>(slope /
                                          F<mshadow_op::square_root>(moving_var + param_.eps),
                                          data.shape_) * data +
             broadcast<1>(bias - (slope * moving_mean) /
                          F<mshadow_op::square_root>(moving_var + param_.eps), data.shape_));

```

ignore the irrelevant signs, and you can see it is the same form as in the original paper.

Actually, what confused me is that when I do this in gpu mode, I dont even set this workspace (use default 512). But when I do this in cpu mode, even I set this to the limit 4096, still it does not work. I am sure my memory is sufficient, what is the point here. Thanks. @piiswrong

Google has recently proposed Apache Beam to provide a unified programming model for distributed execution engines including DataFlow, Spark and Flink. It aims to abstract out the API differences of the various frameworks and should be a more preferable choice.

Also notable is [Splash](http://zhangyuc.github.io/splash/) by @zhangyuc from the UC Berkeley AMPLab. Although the project is still at very early stage, its performance has already been more than a magnitude faster than Spark MLlib.

The proposed [API](http://zhangyuc.github.io/splash/api/) is general enough to integrate MXNet as the concrete algorithm execution engine.

What's your training accuracy? If your training accuracy is not low then I have no idea what could cause this problem. If your training accuracy is low and stays the same, this is probably because you set the learning rate too high and some parameters become NaN. This will makes your model predict all zero.
I don't think you need to change anything in test code if you use your own model.

i think your codes are right if `Copy` do the actually memory copy, rather than just pass the pointer.

the reason might due to the updater's overhead is not small. in sync_dist, there is only one update for each layer in a minibatch, while for async, there are 12 updates. copying `recved` decouples the updating on the same key and therefore improve the performance. 

however, your method might only improve the performance if that layer size is small, e.g. convolution layer. while for big layers such as fully connected, the extra memory copy might be pretty big. 

a possible solution is, copy only if the recved size is `< bigarray_bound_`, which is defined at https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/kvstore/kvstore_local.h#L28

could you please do the following two things
1. confirm that `.Copy` will do the actual memory copy
2. propose a PR to enable your trick if `recved.size < bigarray_bound_`

thanks
